messages.text: Hello. Aside from looping, is there some functional approach to sum all like fields of an array of structures? Such as sum every 'r' field of an image?

text.text: Hello. Aside from looping, is there some functional approach to sum all like fields of an array of structures? Such as sum every 'r' field of an image?

messages.text: Sure, ``` sum(x -> x.r, img) ```

text.text:
Sure,
```
sum(x -> x.r, img)
```

messages.text: Have you specified the environment/project? For the example from <https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/v1/environments/> you'd have to run the script with `julia --project=@. file.jl` if you're in the `MyProject` folder, or `julia --project=path/to/MyProject file.jl` if you're in another folder

messages.text: I thought I understood, but I guess I don't

messages.text: It’s `(1 == 1) |> println`

text.text: It’s `(1 == 1) |> println`

messages.text: If you quote and dump the expression, it’s `(1 == (1 |> println))`

text.text: If you quote and dump the expression, it’s `(1 == (1 |> println))`

messages.text: ohhhh, that makes sense

text.text: ohhhh, that makes sense

messages.text: If you run it, it should print 1 and then return false because `println(1) === nothing`

text.text: If you run it, it should print 1 and then return false because `println(1) === nothing`

messages.text: What is the best way to type function argument that should be a vector of integers? AbstractVector{Integer} is my first guess but will this allow vectors of mixed integer sizes? Are there performance implications in doing so?

text.text: What is the best way to type function argument that should be a vector of integers? AbstractVector{Integer} is my first guess but will this allow vectors of mixed integer sizes? Are there performance implications in doing so?

messages.text: I do f(x::T) where T <: AbstractVector{T2} where T2<:Integer

text.text: I do f(x::T) where T <: AbstractVector{T2} where T2<:Integer

messages.text: The performance degradation comes with the type of the input, if it's a normal Vector{Int64}, it would be fine

text.text: The performance degradation comes with the type of the input, if it's a normal Vector{Int64}, it would be fine

messages.text: If you start pass a vector of mixed elements, there is a performance cost because that vector cannot be stored efficiently in memory

text.text: If you start pass a vector of mixed elements, there is a performance cost because that vector cannot be stored efficiently in memory

messages.text: Is f(x::AbstractVector{<:Integer}) equivalent?

text.text: Is f(x::AbstractVector{<:Integer}) equivalent?

messages.text: Yes, it is

messages.text: Essentially an array lookup that returns a default value, 0 in this case, whenever the given idx is out-of-bounds for the provided array.

text.text: Essentially an array lookup that returns a default value, 0 in this case, whenever the given idx is out-of-bounds for the provided array.

messages.text: You are probably looking for `get([1, 2, 3], 4, 0)`
